subject: SAT
title: Information and Ideas
audience: High school students preparing for the SAT (Reading & Writing)

teacher_notes.pacing: 60–75 minutes; 4 focused sections, each with a worked example and practice.

learning_objectives: Cite textual evidence that best supports a claim.
Interpret and integrate information from charts and tables.
Determine central ideas and key details.
Draw logical inferences from concise passages.

structure.title: Command of Evidence (Textual)
objectives: Select lines that best support a given claim.
Eliminate statements that are true but irrelevant.
Use prediction before scanning options.

lecture_script.script: For evidence items, restate the claim in your own words and seek the sentence that most directly proves it.
I predict: ‘proof that the expedition faced unexpected cold.’ Then I scan for the sentence that explicitly mentions the cold as an obstacle.
Which option is relevant but doesn’t prove the claim? Hold up your letter.

worked_example.passage: Although the plan was meticulous, the hikers turned back when an early storm froze the trail and blocked the pass.
worked_example.question: Which choice best supports the claim that conditions forced a retreat?

options.B: An early storm froze the trail and blocked the pass.
options.D: The pass is popular in summer.

worked_example.explanation: Option B directly states the conditions that caused the retreat.

practice_set.passage: The curator kept the painting in low light because its pigments, fragile with age, faded under stronger lamps.
practice_set.question: Which choice best supports the claim that the curator prioritized preservation?

options.B: It was kept in low light to protect pigments.

structure.title: Command of Evidence (Quantitative)
objectives: Read titles, axes, and units before interpreting values.
Connect visual data to textual claims.
Avoid overgeneralizing beyond the figure.

lecture_script.script: Always parse the figure: title, variables, scale, and trend. Then match the exact claim to the exact data point or pattern.
We’ll annotate a small table and cross-check which option accurately cites the numbers.
If the claim says ‘largest increase,’ what two numbers must we compare? Answer in one phrase.

worked_example.passage: Figure: A table shows year 1 = 40 participants, year 2 = 50, year 3 = 70 in a school science fair.
worked_example.question: Which statement is best supported by the table?

options.A: Participation decreased from year 1 to year 3.
options.B: The largest increase occurred between years 2 and 3.
options.C: Year 2 had the most participants overall.
options.D: Year 1 and year 2 had equal participation.

worked_example.explanation: Values rise 40→50 (+10) then 50→70 (+20); the larger increase is 2 to 3.

practice_set.passage: Figure: A bar chart shows library visits per month: Jan 200, Feb 220, Mar 260.
practice_set.question: Which choice accurately describes the trend?

structure.title: Central Ideas & Details
objectives: Identify a passage’s main claim.
Differentiate central ideas from minor details.
Use wording that paraphrases rather than copies.

lecture_script.script: Main ideas explain the passage’s purpose. Details serve that purpose. Prefer options that capture the whole point without overspecifying.
We’ll reject a choice that quotes a detail but misses the broader claim.
Underline the author’s purpose verb and complete the sentence: ‘The author argues that…’

worked_example.passage: Community gardens, beyond supplying produce, build trust among neighbors who meet regularly to plan, plant, and share the harvest.
worked_example.question: Which choice states the central idea?

options.B: Community gardens foster social connections in addition to food.

worked_example.explanation: The sentence emphasizes both produce and building trust-social connections beyond food.

practice_set.passage: The biography notes that early failures taught the artist techniques later evident in widely praised works.
practice_set.question: What is the central idea?

structure.title: Inferences
objectives: Make logical conclusions supported by the text.
Avoid speculation beyond the passage.
Use evidence to justify the inference.

lecture_script.script: An inference is a justified conclusion, not a guess. Ask: If the text is true, what must also be true?
The narrator ‘checks the door twice’; I infer anxiety or caution because the action signals concern about security.
Which choice goes beyond the text? Call it when you hear unrelated claims.

worked_example.passage: Hearing the thunder grow nearer, Lina moved the metal chairs indoors before locking the garden gate.
worked_example.question: What can be reasonably inferred about Lina?

options.B: She anticipates risk and acts to prevent damage.
options.C: She plans to sell the chairs.

worked_example.explanation: She moves metal chairs and locks the gate as the storm approaches-preventive action shows anticipation of risk.

practice_set.passage: When the auditorium lights dimmed, the presenter paused until the last whispers faded, then began.
practice_set.question: What is the most reasonable inference?

options.C: The presenter waited for attention before starting.

Text 1 says urban trees cool streets; Text 2 notes shade lowers energy use. They complement the same idea: cooling benefits.
Is the proposed statement true for both texts? If not, it’s out.

teacher_notes.pacing: 60 minutes; 3 sections with quick practice and feedback.
teacher_notes.materials: Slide deck with example transitions, sample sources for synthesis, and style/tone examples.
teacher_notes.assessment: Unit check and review of edited sentences in guided practice.

learning_objectives: Choose precise transitions that reflect logic between ideas.
Synthesize information from a short source set to support a claim.
Maintain consistent style and tone appropriate to context.

structure.title: Transitions
objectives: Match transition type to relationship (addition, contrast, cause).
Eliminate grammatically fine but illogical connectors.
Test by paraphrasing the link in simple words.

lecture_script.script: Identify the relationship between sentences first. Then pick a transition that states that relationship-no fancier than needed.
We’ll replace vague connectors with specific ones that show contrast or cause-and-effect.
State the link in two words: ‘therefore’ or ‘however’? Choose accordingly.

worked_example.passage: The proposal is affordable; however, it lacks a plan for maintenance costs after year one.
worked_example.question: Which transition best fits the relationship?
worked_example.explanation: The second clause contrasts a strength with a weakness; ‘however’ signals contrast.

practice_set.passage: The solar array cut energy use by 20%; therefore, monthly costs fell noticeably.
practice_set.question: The transition primarily shows

structure.title: Rhetorical Synthesis
objectives: Select evidence that best supports a stated claim from multiple sources.
Avoid irrelevant but interesting facts.
Combine concise paraphrases from two brief sources.

lecture_script.script: Underline the claim, then pick data that directly advances that claim. If it doesn’t support, it doesn’t belong.
Claim: school gardens improve nutrition. Source A shows increased veggie intake; Source B shows more students trying new produce-both support the claim.
Which source sentence actually proves the claim? Give the letter only.

worked_example.passage: Claim: Later school start times improve attendance. Source 1: After shifting to 8:45 a.m., tardies fell by 30%. Source 2: Students reported feeling more rested.
worked_example.question: Which statement best supports the claim?

options.B: Tardies fell by 30% after a later start.

worked_example.explanation: The 30% drop in tardies directly supports improved attendance.

practice_set.passage: Claim: Adding shade trees lowers building energy use. Source A: Shaded walls absorb less heat. Source B: Meter readings fell 12% after tree planting.
practice_set.question: Which choice best supports the claim?

structure.title: Style & Tone
objectives: Maintain a consistent formal or informal tone.
Choose concise, precise phrasing over wordiness.
Avoid slang or jargon that clashes with context.

lecture_script.script: Match the register to the audience. Academic contexts prefer concise and neutral phrasing.
We’ll revise sentences to remove wordiness and adjust tone from casual to formal.
Is this phrase too casual for a report? Answer yes or no.

worked_example.passage: Original: The experiment was kind of a big deal because it, like, showed cool results. Revision options vary in formality and precision.
worked_example.question: Which revision maintains an appropriately formal tone?

options.A: The experiment was kinda big ‘cause it showed cool results.
options.B: The experiment was important because it demonstrated clear results.
options.C: The experiment was, you know, interesting.
options.D: The experiment was epic and wild.

worked_example.explanation: Option B is concise and formal, avoiding slang and vagueness.

practice_set.passage: Choose the most concise, formal option to complete: ‘The committee decided to ___ the plan for clarity.’
practice_set.question: Which choice best fits?

options.B: completely and totally overhaul in a manner that is thorough
evidence that advances the stated claim

homework: Edit a paragraph by replacing three weak transitions with precise ones and justify each choice.
From two short sources, select two sentences that best support a given claim.
Revise five sentences to align tone with a formal report.

subject: SAT
title: Standard English Conventions
audience: High school students preparing for the SAT (Reading & Writing)

teacher_notes.pacing: 60–75 minutes; 3 grammar-focused sections with quick drills.
teacher_notes.materials: Slide deck, grammar reference sheet, and mini whiteboards for response.
teacher_notes.assessment: Unit check and correction of common errors from practice.

learning_objectives: Edit sentences for clarity and correct structure.
Apply punctuation rules for commas, dashes, and colons.
Ensure subject-verb and pronoun-antecedent agreement.

structure.title: Sentence Structure
objectives: Identify and correct fragments and run-ons.
Use subordination and coordination appropriately.
Choose concise, logically complete sentences.

lecture_script.script: Complete sentences need a subject and a finite verb and express a full idea. Join related ideas with proper punctuation or conjunctions.
We’ll fix two run-ons by adding conjunctions or splitting into two sentences, keeping meaning concise.
Is this a fragment, a run-on, or correct? Hold up F, R, or C.

worked_example.passage: The museum expanded last year it opened two new galleries devoted to modern art.
worked_example.question: Which choice best corrects the sentence?

options.A: The museum expanded last year opening two new galleries devoted to modern art.
options.B: The museum expanded last year; it opened two new galleries devoted to modern art.
options.C: Because the museum expanded last year, and opened two new galleries devoted to modern art.
options.D: The museum expanded last year, it opened two new galleries devoted to modern art.

worked_example.explanation: Option B correctly joins two independent clauses with a semicolon.

practice_set.passage: Hoping to finish early and to catch the bus on time.
practice_set.question: Which revision creates a complete sentence?

options.A: Hoping to finish early, the team worked quickly and caught the bus.
options.B: Hoping to finish early; and to catch the bus on time.
options.C: Hoping to finish early catching the bus on time.
options.D: Hoping to finish early on time bus.

structure.title: Punctuation
objectives: Use commas for nonessential information and series.
Apply colons to introduce explanations or lists.
Use dashes for emphasis or appositives when appropriate.

lecture_script.script: Commas set off nonessential phrases; colons follow complete clauses to introduce explanations; dashes can replace commas for emphasis.
We’ll test whether the clause before a colon is complete, then decide between comma, colon, or dash.
Is the information essential? If not, set it off with commas or dashes.

worked_example.passage: The recipe calls for three ingredients simple ones: flour, water, and salt.
worked_example.question: Which choice correctly uses punctuation?

options.A: The recipe calls for three ingredients: simple ones, flour, water, and salt.
options.B: The recipe calls for three ingredients-simple ones: flour, water, and salt.
options.C: The recipe calls for three ingredients: simple ones-flour, water, and salt.
options.D: The recipe calls for three ingredients: flour, water, and salt.

worked_example.explanation: A complete clause precedes a colon that introduces a list; no extra words are needed.

practice_set.passage: The festival featured dancers musicians and poets from across the region.
practice_set.question: Which choice correctly punctuates the sentence?

options.A: The festival featured dancers, musicians, and poets from across the region.
options.B: The festival featured dancers; musicians and poets from across the region.
options.C: The festival featured dancers musicians, and poets, from across the region.
options.D: The festival featured dancers-musicians-and poets from across the region.

structure.title: Usage & Agreement
objectives: Ensure subject-verb agreement, even with interrupting phrases.
Maintain pronoun clarity and agreement in number and person.
Choose precise, conventional usage over awkward phrasing.

lecture_script.script: Match the verb to the true subject, not to nearby nouns. Keep pronouns clear and consistent with their antecedents.
We’ll identify subjects in tricky sentences and adjust verbs or pronouns accordingly.
State the subject and the correct verb form in two words each.

worked_example.passage: The bouquet of roses and lilies were fragrant enough to fill the room.
worked_example.question: Which choice corrects the error?

options.A: The bouquet of roses and lilies was fragrant enough to fill the room.
options.B: The bouquets of roses and lilies was fragrant enough to fill the room.
options.C: The bouquet of roses and lilies were fragrant enough to fill the rooms.
options.D: The bouquet of roses and lilies are fragrant enough to fill the room.

worked_example.explanation: Subject is ‘bouquet’ (singular), so the verb should be ‘was.’

practice_set.passage: Neither the coach nor the players ___ ready for the photo when it was taken.
practice_set.question: Which verb correctly completes the sentence?

options.B: a subject and a finite verb

options.A: set off with commas or dashes

homework: Fix ten sentences containing fragments, run-ons, or comma splices.
Add correct punctuation to five sentences with lists or explanations.
Revise five sentences for agreement and clear pronoun reference.

subject: SAT
title: Advanced Reading Comprehension
audience: High school students preparing for the SAT (Reading & Writing)

teacher_notes.pacing: 75 minutes; 3 advanced sections with paired and domain passages.
teacher_notes.materials: Paired passage handouts, historical documents, and short science/social science texts.
teacher_notes.assessment: 4-item unit check and review of evidence selection.

learning_objectives: Analyze and compare claims in paired passages.
Interpret historical documents with attention to purpose and audience.
Apply domain-reading strategies for science and social science texts.

structure.title: Paired Passages
objectives: Identify each passage’s main claim and evidence.
Determine agreement, disagreement, or qualification.
Synthesize points into a single accurate statement.

lecture_script.script: Read Passage 1 for claim and proof, then Passage 2 for response. Ask: support, qualify, or oppose? Choose an option true for both.
We’ll chart each passage’s claim in five words, then write one synthesis sentence that captures the relationship.
If an option misstates either claim, it’s out. Give the letter that fits both.

worked_example.passage: Passage 1: A community garden increases local produce access. Passage 2: The garden also strengthens neighbor ties through shared work.
worked_example.question: Together, the passages suggest that the garden
worked_example.explanation: P1 emphasizes produce access; P2 emphasizes community ties-both nutritional and social benefits.

practice_set.passage: Passage 1: The museum should digitize archives to widen access. Passage 2: Digitization is useful but must protect fragile originals.
practice_set.question: The relationship between the passages is best described as

structure.title: Historical Documents
objectives: Identify author’s purpose and audience.
Interpret claims within historical context using only provided text.
Evaluate rhetoric such as appeals and structure.

lecture_script.script: Focus on purpose, audience, and claim. Paraphrase archaic words, but base answers only on the text provided.
If a petition ‘respectfully urges’ reform, the tone is formal and persuasive toward officials-aimed at policy change.
State audience and purpose in six words or fewer.

worked_example.passage: The letter, addressed to the city council, requests that public funds support a free night school so workers may study after hours.
worked_example.question: The author’s primary purpose is to
worked_example.explanation: The letter requests funding for a public night school-persuasion aimed at officials.

practice_set.passage: In the proclamation, the governor thanks volunteers and calls for continued service to aid communities after the storm.
practice_set.question: The document’s tone and purpose are best described as

options.B: formal appreciation with a call to action

structure.title: Science & Social Science Focus
objectives: Extract claims, evidence, and limitations from domain texts.
Translate data statements into plain language.
Avoid introducing outside knowledge beyond the passage and figure.

lecture_script.script: Scientific and social science texts center on claims supported by data. Identify the claim, the measure, and the relationship between variables.
We’ll read a brief findings summary and paraphrase the pattern described by the numbers.
Does the option accurately reflect the stated trend? Yes or no only.

worked_example.passage: Report: Students using spaced review scored 8 points higher on average than those who crammed the night before.
worked_example.question: Which statement is best supported by the report?

options.B: Spaced review is associated with higher average scores.

worked_example.explanation: The report links spaced review with higher average scores; no absolute claims are made.

practice_set.passage: Study: Towns adding bus lanes saw commute times drop from 40 to 32 minutes on average.
practice_set.question: Which choice accurately summarizes the finding?

options.B: Commute times fell by about eight minutes on average.

homework: Write one-sentence claim summaries for two paired passages and state the relationship.
Annotate a historical paragraph for audience, purpose, and tone.
Paraphrase three findings from short science/social science blurbs.

subject: SAT
title: Mixed Practice & Test Strategies
audience: High school students preparing for the SAT (Reading & Writing)

teacher_notes.pacing: 60–75 minutes; 3 sections with timed drills and review.
teacher_notes.materials: Timer, mixed item sets, and reflection sheets for strategy notes.
teacher_notes.assessment: 4-item unit check and exit reflection on pacing decisions.

learning_objectives: Apply strategies across mixed Reading & Writing items.
Manage time with deliberate skipping and flagging.
Recognize and avoid common traps and pitfalls.

structure.title: Mixed Question Sets
objectives: Switch efficiently between item types.
Use read–predict–select across diverse passages.
Justify choices with brief evidence.

lecture_script.script: On mixed sets, label the question type quickly, predict, then select while eliminating by relevance and precision.
We’ll complete a 3-item mini set under time, then debrief choices in one sentence each.
State the evidence phrase that made your answer correct.

worked_example.passage: The beekeeper recorded hive weights weekly, noting that supplemental flowers near the fence correlated with steadier gains.
worked_example.question: Which choice best states the main idea?

options.B: Nearby flowers were associated with steadier weight gains.

worked_example.explanation: The sentence links supplemental flowers with steadier gains-central relationship.

practice_set.passage: The editor cut redundant phrases so the article would read quickly and clearly.
practice_set.question: The edit primarily aims to improve

practice_set.passage: Figure: A line rises from 10 to 18 between trials 1 and 4.
practice_set.question: Which statement is supported by the figure?

structure.title: Time Management Drills
objectives: Apply guess-and-flag when stuck.
Use micro-benchmarks to pace work.
Avoid spending more than 30 seconds before moving on.

lecture_script.script: Protect later points by setting 20–30 second decision windows. Make a best choice, flag, and continue.
Run a two-minute drill: answer three items, flag one if needed, and return.
Share one item you flagged and why-you protected time for later points.

worked_example.passage: During a drill, Sam quickly eliminated two options as off-topic, chose the better of the remaining two, and flagged the item.
worked_example.question: Sam’s approach primarily demonstrates
worked_example.explanation: Elimination plus flagging reflects strategic pacing decisions.

practice_set.passage: Facing a dense sentence, Alia selected an answer, flagged the item, and finished the last three questions on time.
practice_set.question: What strategy is illustrated?

structure.title: Common Pitfalls & Review
objectives: Avoid choices that are true but not relevant.
Watch for extreme or absolute wording when the passage is moderate.
Check that grammar edits preserve meaning.

lecture_script.script: Most traps are tempting because they echo the text without answering the question or use extreme language not supported by the passage.
We’ll dissect a distractor that is factually correct but irrelevant and a choice with ‘always’ that overreaches the evidence.
Write one trap pattern you will watch for on test day.

worked_example.passage: Researchers observed that moderate exercise was associated with improved mood in most participants during weekdays.
worked_example.question: Which choice is an overgeneralization?

options.A: Moderate exercise was linked to better mood on weekdays.
options.B: Exercise always guarantees happiness for everyone.

worked_example.explanation: ‘Always’ and ‘everyone’ go beyond the study’s limited claim.

practice_set.passage: The author praises a program for reducing food waste but notes it requires consistent volunteer hours.
practice_set.question: Which choice is not supported?

options.C: The author completely opposes the program.
options.D: There is a noted requirement for effort.

unit_check.question: When stuck for 30 seconds, you should

homework: Complete a 12-item mixed set under time and annotate trap patterns.
Create a personal pacing plan with checkpoints every 5 minutes.
Write three ‘if stuck, then’ rules you will apply on test day.
